DOCNAME: CASE OF INFORMATIONSVEREIN LENTIA AND OTHERS v. AUSTRIA
CONCLUSION: Violation of Art. 10;Not necessary to examine Art. 14+10;Pecuniary damage - claim dismissed;Costs and expenses partial award - domestic proceedings;Costs and expenses partial award - Convention proceedings
TEXT: CARDINAL . The first applicant , an association of co - proprietors and residents of a housing development in GPE , comprising CARDINAL apartments and CARDINAL businesses , proposed to improve the communication between its members by setting up an internal cable television network . The programmes were to be confined to questions of mutual interest concerning ORG rights .

CARDINAL . On DATE the first applicant applied for an operating licence under LAW , see paragraph CARDINAL below ) . As ORG and ORG ( Post- PERSON ) had not replied within the DATE time - limit laid down in LAW ) , the association applied to ORG ( Generaldirektion für die Post- PERSON ) , attached to ORG ) .

ORG rejected the application on DATE . In its view , Article CARDINAL para . CARDINAL of LAW guaranteeing the independence of broadcasting ( GPE über die GPE der ORG , " LAW " , see paragraph CARDINAL below ) had vested in the federal legislature exclusive authority to regulate this activity ; it had exercised that authority only once , by enacting the PERSON on ORG ( Bundesgesetz über die PERSON ORG , see paragraph CARDINAL below ) . It followed that no other person could apply for such licence as any application would lack a legal basis . Furthermore there had been no violation of LAW ) of the Convention since the legislature - in its capacity as a maker of constitutional laws ( PERSON ) - had merely availed itself of its power to set up a system of licences in accordance with the third sentence of paragraph CARDINAL ( article CARDINAL ) .
CARDINAL . Thereupon the first applicant complained to ORG of a breach of LAW ) ; the court gave judgment on DATE .

It took the view that the freedom to set up and operate radio and television broadcasting stations was subject to the powers accorded to the legislature under paragraph CARDINAL in fine and paragraph CARDINAL of Article CARDINAL ( article CARDINAL , article LAW ) ( PERSON ) . Accordingly , an administrative decision could infringe that provision only if it proved to have no legal basis , or its legal basis was unconstitutional or again had been applied in an arbitrary manner ( in denkunmöglicher Weise an[ge]wendet ) . In addition , LAW had instituted a system which made all activity of this type subject to the grant of a licence ( ORG ) by the federal legislature . This system was intended to ensure objectivity and diversity of opinions ( ORG ) , and would be ineffective if it were possible for everybody to obtain the requisite authorisation . As matters stood , the right to broadcast was restricted to ORG ( ORG , ORG ) , as no implementing legislation had been enacted in addition to the law governing that organisation .

Contrary to its assertions , the first applicant had in fact intended to broadcast within the meaning of the constitutional law , because its programmes were to be directed at a general audience of variable composition . The broadcasting law therefore provided a legal basis for the decision in issue .
Consequently , ORG rejected the complaint and remitted it to ORG .
CARDINAL . On DATE ORG in substance adopted the grounds relied on by ORG and in its turn dismissed the first applicant ’s claim .

CARDINAL . From DATE to DATE the second applicant elaborated a project for the setting up , with other persons , of a private radio station in GPE . He subsequently gave up the idea after a study had shown him that according to the applicable law as interpreted by ORG he would not be able to obtain the necessary licence . As a result he never applied for CARDINAL .

The third applicant , an NORP association and a member of the ORG européenne des radios libres ( ORG ) , plans to establish a radio station in southern LOC in order to broadcast , in NORP and LANGUAGE , non - commercial radio programmes , whose makers already operate an authorised mobile radio station in GPE .

CARDINAL . In DATE ORG applied for a licence . Its application was refused by ORG and ORG on DATE and by ORG in GPE on DATE . On DATE , on the basis of its own case - law ( see paragraph CARDINAL above ) , ORG dismissed an appeal from that decision .

CARDINAL . The fourth applicant is a shareholder of an NORP company operating a commercial radio which broadcasts to GPE and he wishes to carry out the same activity in that country . However , in view of the legislation in force , he decided not to make any application to the appropriate authorities .

CARDINAL . The fifth applicant is a private limited company incorporated under NORP law . On DATE it asked ORG and ORG to allocate it a frequency so that it could operate a local radio station which it hoped to launch in GPE . On DATE its application was rejected , a decision confirmed on CARDINAL DATE by ORG and on DATE by ORG , which based its decision on its judgment of DATE ( see paragraph CARDINAL above ) .

CARDINAL . According to LAW , " the right to set up and operate telecommunications installations ( Fernmeldeanlagen ) is vested exclusively in the federal authorities ( GPE ) " ( LAW para . CARDINAL ) . The latter may however confer on natural or legal persons the power to exercise that right in respect of specific installations ( Article CARDINAL para . CARDINAL ) . No licence is required in certain circumstances , including the setting up of an installation within the confines of a private property ( DATE ) .

CARDINAL . The Ministerial Ordinance of DATE concerning private telecommunications installations lays down inter alia the conditions for setting up and operating private telecommunications installations subject to federal supervision . According to the case - law , it can not however constitute the legal basis for the grant of licences .
CARDINAL . According to LAW DATE guaranteeing the independence of broadcasting ,

CARDINAL . Broadcasting shall be governed by more detailed rules to be set out in a federal law . Such a law must inter alia contain provisions guaranteeing the objectivity and impartiality of reporting , the diversity of opinions , balanced programming and the independence of persons and bodies responsible for carrying out the duties defined in paragraph CARDINAL .
CARDINAL . Broadcasting within the meaning of paragraph CARDINAL shall be a public service . "
CARDINAL . The Law of DATE on ORG established ORG with the status of an autonomous public - law corporation .

It is under a duty to provide comprehensive news coverage of major political , economic , cultural and sporting events ; to this end , it has to broadcast , in compliance with the requirements of objectivity and diversity of views , in particular current affairs , news reports , commentaries and critical opinions ( Article CARDINAL para . CARDINAL ( CARDINAL ) ) , and to do so via CARDINAL television channels and CARDINAL radio stations , CARDINAL of which must be a regional station ( Article CARDINAL ) . Broadcasting time must be allocated to the political parties represented in the national parliament and to representative associations ( Article CARDINAL para . CARDINAL ) .

A supervisory board ( ORG ) rules on all disputes concerning the application of the above - mentioned law which fall outside the jurisdiction of an administrative authority or court ( Articles CARDINAL and DATE ) . It is composed of CARDINAL independent members , including CARDINAL judges , appointed for terms of DATE by the President of the Republic on the proposal of ORG .

CARDINAL . On DATE ORG decided that LAW of DATE ( see paragraph CARDINAL above ) did not cover " passive " broadcasting via cable , in other words the broadcasting in their entirety by cable of programmes picked up by an aerial . Consequently , the mere fact that such programmes originated from a foreign station and were directed principally or exclusively at an NORP audience could not constitute grounds for refusing the licence necessary for this type of operation .

CARDINAL . On DATE a PERSON on regional radio stations is to enter into force ( NORP , PERSON ( ORG ) no . CARDINAL/CARDINAL ) . It will allow the authorities under certain conditions to grant private individuals or private corporations licences to set up and operate regional radio stations .
